Course Level: Intermediate This new course, aimed at second semester sophomores, is the launch pad of Television Writing in the department. Before taking any other TV writing courses, students must take Introduction To Television Writing. The course will introduce sophomores interested in TV writing to all aspects of what goes into the creation of a script for a TV program. It is also recommended for non-writers who wish to learn the fundamentals of TV writing as preparation for creating shows and working with writers. The course will also prepare students for other TV-writing courses in the departmental Television Progression. Half-hour comedy, both multi-cam and single cam, and Hour-long drama are the main focus of the course. Students will learn how to come up with storylines, what outlines and treatments entail, the difference between writing for primetime network and cable, collaboration, what it’s like to be on a writing staff, creating an original Pilot and all aspects of writing for television. After taking Introduction To Television Writing, students will be ready to decide whether to move into comedy writing, hour-long drama writing or both. The course is also open to seniors with an interest in television writing who haven’t taken other TV writing courses. Dramatic Writing Television Pilot Collaboration (Spring 2014)     Graduate students Kimberly Barrante, April Brassard, Josh Daws, Rachel Ewing, Krystal Foster, Joseph Mango, Dan Marmor, Nathaniel Shapiro, Ashley Sims, Cory Terry, and Erin Triplett wrote and produced a half-hour television sitcom in collaboration with the undergraduate Department of Film and Television including students Hollie Bennett, Nathan Glassman-Hughes, Matt Heymann, Nick Johnson, John Loxterkamp, Danielle Massie, Grant Ogden, Alex Piccolo, Michelle Rosique, Alex Sarete, and Lily van Leeuwen.         The pilot, titled "Released", was filmed in the television studio at Tisch under faculty advisors Dean Sheril Antonio, Charlie Rubin (DDW), James Felder (DDW), Gary Shimokawa (Film/TV), Rosanne Limoncelli (Film/TV), and Lauren Fritz (Film/TV). "Released" was directed by Tisch Film/TV alum Esteban Pedraza; Assistant Director: Jack Kyser, also a Tisch Film/TV alumni.         Featuring the cast of Arturo Castro, Cassie Okenka, David Sitler, Anne Mulford, Adam Bradley, Saluda Camp, and Jim Tierney. Advanced TV Writing: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Undergraduate Film & Television Admissions About the Program Course Offerings Summer Courses Showcase Internships Facilities Special Projects First Run & Festivals Calendar of Events News TSOA FTV Wiki Admin & Faculty Alumni Blog Facebook Twitter YouTube  home > Undergraduate Film & TV        Advanced Television Writing: One Hour Drama  FMTV-UT.1132 Studio 4 Credits Course Level: Advanced    Prerequisite: Fundamentals of Dramatic and Visual Writing (H56.0033), or Dramatic & Visual Writing II (H56.0032), or Script Writing II (H56.0056). Starting Spring 2010, this course will require Writing the Short Screenplay (H56.1020) or Script Analysis (H56.1084).    Students are given the choice of writing an Original Pilot or a Spec Script for an existing hour-long drama. The course examines the structure and storytelling techniques necessary to write a 60-minute script--A, B, C and D stories. Students choosing to write a Spec for an existing show will begin by pitching their story ideas, writing an outline, then moving on to the first draft of a script. Those who choose to write an Original Pilot will start by presenting their premise, characters and storylines before moving on to an outline and the script. Each week we will read scripts from current shows or watch episodes of specific hour-long dramas to study their structure and plotting.
